title: Science of Star Trek
summary: Neil deGrasse Tyson and guest scientists discuss the real science behind Star Trek, including space travel, alien life, and futuristic technology.
utterances: How realistic is warp drive, really?
Star Trek imagined tablets before iPads existed.
The Prime Directive: would it ever work in human space exploration?
transcript: Tyson and physicist guests critique transporters, the plausibility of alien societies, and the technology that has gone from sci-fi to science fact.

title: Life on Mars
summary: Explores current missions to Mars, evidence of water, and the latest search for signs of Martian life.
utterances: The real science behind NASA’s Mars landers.
What can Mars geology tell us about habitability?
If there’s life, where are we most likely to find it?
transcript: Planetary scientists and astrobiologists break down new discoveries, and Neil offers insight into the future of Mars rovers.

title: The Physics of Superheroes
summary: Analyzes the scientific plausibility of superhero abilities, from Spider-Man’s webs to Iron Man’s suit, with guest physicists.
utterances: Could anyone really swing between skyscrapers?
Iron Man’s suit: what science would be required?
Why the Hulk couldn’t actually exist—biochemically.
transcript: Popular science discussions and laughs with Dr. Charles Liu, demystifying what’s possible and what’s pure comic book fantasy.

title: Cosmic Collisions
summary: Focuses on asteroids, comets, and the frequency and risk of major impacts on Earth.
utterances: What’s the biggest known impact in solar system history?
Are we prepared for a major asteroid threat?
What are the odds of a civilization-ending event in our lifetime?
transcript: Tyson investigates past extinctions, planetary impacts, and how science and policy could prevent future catastrophe.

title: The Science of Comedy
summary: Explores the neuroscience and psychology behind humor, with comedians and brain scientists discussing why we laugh.
utterances: Why do humans have a sense of humor?
Comedians riff on what makes science cringe-worthy.
Laughter and learning are closely linked.
transcript: Neuroscience of laughter is explored alongside stand-up routines and science jokes, with recurring co-host Chuck Nice.

title: Women in Science
summary: Spotlights the trailblazers in STEM, examining the challenges and triumphs of women in science and engineering fields.
utterances: Encouraging women in science starts early.
Role models shape the next generation.
Why has physics been slower to diversify?
transcript: Interviews with leading women in astrophysics, biology, and NASA, highlighting progress and persistent obstacles.

title: The Science of Star Wars
summary: From lightsabers to droids, Tyson and guests break down Star Wars tech and its physics with a playful touch.
utterances: Could you ever really build a lightsaber?
Why droid behavior is more plausible than you think.
Does any planet make sense scientifically?
transcript: Myth-busting sessions with roboticists and astronomers make Star Wars more fun than ever for science nuts.

title: Aliens: The Fermi Paradox
summary: What are the odds of alien life—and if it exists, why haven’t we heard from it? Explores Fermi’s question and the Drake Equation.
utterances: The universe is big, so where is everybody?
SETI is listening harder than you know.
Missed signals or rare life: which is it?
transcript: Neil and SETI Institute researchers break down the best guesses and what would actually happen if we got a signal.

title: Black Holes & Time Warps
summary: Discusses the science and fantasy of black holes, time dilation, and what would happen if you fell in.
utterances: Event horizons are the point of no return.
Time travel is science fiction—mostly.
Black holes might power the universe’s strangest phenomena.
transcript: Astrophysicists explain wormholes, general relativity, and why we’re still obsessed with space-time.

title: StarTalk Live! with Bill Nye
summary: Special episode recorded live with Bill Nye ‘The Science Guy’, answering listener questions from evolution to the space race.
utterances: Bill Nye inspires a new wave of STEM fans.
Live Q&A makes for surprising science tangents.
Sometimes the best answers are jokes.
transcript: Bill and Neil riff on rocket history, misunderstandings in pop science, and STEM outreach.

title: The Future of Humanity
summary: Examines big predictions about the next century: genetic engineering, AI, and space colonization.
utterances: What would it really mean to colonize Mars?
Can biotechnology ‘upgrade’ the human body?
AI and ethics go hand in hand.
transcript: Philosophers and technologists weigh pros and cons of bold future paths.

title: Space Tourism
summary: Can private enterprise make commercial spaceflight a near-future reality? With Virgin Galactic and SpaceX leaders.
utterances: Will space tourism be affordable in our lifetimes?
SpaceX vs. Virgin: Who will get there first?
Microgravity vacations—are you in?
transcript: Industry leaders discuss launches, legalities, and training for the paying space passenger.

title: Music of the Cosmos
summary: How do planets, stars, and nebulae inspire music and sound design? Astrophysics meets creativity.
utterances: Sound can't travel in a vacuum—so why so much cosmic music?
Musicians and scientists decode astronomical influences.
What would a neutron star sound like?
transcript: Composers and physicists collaborate to make sense of cosmic harmonies and sonic representations.

title: Secrets of the Moon
summary: The story of lunar formation, moon missions, and why Earth’s only natural satellite still holds so many mysteries.
utterances: Apollo missions were only the beginning.
What explains the moon’s dark side?
Lunar geology is a puzzle still being solved.
transcript: Tyson explores lunar geology, ancient myths, and modern NASA mission designs.

title: Sports Science
summary: What does science say about athletic performance, physics of motion, and the boundaries of human achievement?
utterances: Why can’t a human run a two-hour marathon—yet?
Biomechanics and nutrition for record chasers.
The science behind sports myths.
transcript: Coaches, athletes, and engineers break down human limits, training, and surprising facts about the body.

title: Quantum Weirdness
summary: Demystifies entanglement, the observer effect, and the spookiest results of quantum physics with world-leading experts.
utterances: Quantum mechanics isn’t just weird, it’s essential.
Entanglement is the universe’s wildest magic trick.
Is reality truly probabilistic?
transcript: Theoretical physicists reveal strange facts and what quantum tech could enable next.

title: Dinosaurs and Other Ancient Life
summary: Paleontologists dig into mass extinctions, dino biology, and the search for new fossils.
utterances: T. rex is just the tip of the fossil iceberg.
What killed off the dinosaurs, and could it happen again?
Ancient DNA lets us see the past clearer than ever.
transcript: Neil and guests crack open fossil history, connect Earth history to climate cycles, and the science of Jurassic Park.

title: Origin of the Elements
summary: How do stars make elements, and what’s the cosmic chemistry that shapes planets and life?
utterances: Every atom in your body comes from a star.
Periodic table stories go cosmic.
Supernovae create and destroy worlds.
transcript: Physicists and chemists describe nuclear fusion, the birth of new elements, and the search for exotic isotopes.

title: The Science of Cooking
summary: Chefs and food chemists serve up the science of flavor, fermentation, and why some recipes just work.
utterances: The Maillard reaction explains why we love seared food.
Fermented foods and probiotics—are they healing or hype?
How does your brain really taste sugar?
transcript: Neil and culinary inventors explain how cooking is chemistry—and how to hack it.

title: Neuroscience and the Brain
summary: What do we really know about the brain? Neuroscientists discuss memory, consciousness, and big mysteries that research hasn't cracked yet.
utterances: How does your memory work—and why does it fail?
Consciousness remains the biggest unsolved problem.
Is AI getting closer to brain-like thinking?
transcript: Neil and leading neuroscientists review mapping the brain, cures for disease, and the philosophy of mind.
